3.72.text: DNA sequencing is the process of working out

7.08.text: the order of the building blocks, or bases, in a strand of DNA.

13.36.text:
Before we can sequence the DNA, it has to
be cut up into smaller pieces

19.52.text: that are inserted into plasmid DNA

24.54.text: and then put into bacterial cells.

28.76.text:
This makes it possible to produce lots and
lots of copies of it

37.10.text:
The DNA is then isolated from the bacteria
and sent for sequencing.

43.78.text:
The isolated DNA is transferred to a plate
where the sequencing reaction will take place.

52.37.text: A mixture of ingredients is added.

54.95.text: These include free DNA bases (A, C, G, T),

68.72.text:
Modified DNA bases labelled with coloured,
fluorescent tags are also added.

84.20.text:
To start the sequencing reaction, everything
is heated to 96 degrees Celsius.

90.63.text: This separates the DNA into two single strands.

95.78.text: The temperature is then lowered to 50 degrees.

99.86.text:
This enables the DNA primers to bind to the
plasmid DNA.

104.72.text: The temperature is then increased to 60 degrees

107.94.text: and the enzyme DNA polymerase binds to the primer DNA.

113.06.text: DNA polymerase starts making a new strand of DNA

117.65.text: by adding unlabelled DNA bases to the target DNA.

123.45.text:
It continues to add DNA bases until a terminator
base is added.

129.35.text: These terminator bases have been chemically altered

132.45.text: so that no more bases can be added to the new strand of DNA.

137.58.text: Once a terminator base is added, the DNA polymerase enzyme

142.12.text: stops making DNA and falls away from the strand.

146.54.text: Everything is then heated to 96 degrees Celsius again

150.70.text: to separate the new DNA strand from the original strand.

158.12.text: This process of heating and cooling is repeated again and again

162.98.text: to produce lots of fragments of DNA of different lengths.

171.86.text:
The length of each fragment depends on when
a terminator base got added.

188.60.text:
To read the sequence of the DNA the various
fragments are separated by length

198.16.text:
A capillary tube is lowered into each well
of the plate and an electrical charge is applied.

204.75.text:
This causes the negatively-charged DNA molecules
to move through the capillary tube.

212.41.text: Each capillary contains a porous gel.

216.21.text:
The shorter fragments of DNA move through
the gel more easily than the longer DNA fragments.

225.31.text:
As a result, the fragments become arranged
by size, from the shortest to the longest.

233.14.text: As the DNA fragments come to the end of the capillary,

236.90.text: a laser makes the terminator bases light up.

240.56.text: The colour is detected by a camera and recorded.

245.14.text: Each terminator base is labelled with a different colour.

248.92.text: ‘A’ fluoresces green, ‘C’ blue, ‘G’ yellow, and ‘T’ red.

260.18.text:
The shortest DNA fragments will be read first,
and the longest read last.

267.50.text:
The sequencing machine records the colour
of the terminator bases as a series of coloured blocks.

274.68.text:
Each coloured block represents the labelled,
terminator base at the end of each fragment of DNA.

282.72.text:
By converting the colours into letters we
get the sequence of our piece of DNA.
